boardgame.name: Relics of Power Redux
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A MESSAGE FROM BEYOND TIME...

Challenge yourself and your players with this new take on the quintessential original Relics of Power adventure trilogy (The Destiny Map, The Possibility Chalice, and The Forever City), brought back by popular demand!

Storm Knights criss-cross the globe to face down agents of many High Lords in their Cosms, including the Nile Empire, Cyberpapacy, and Pan-Pacifica. Their goal: the secrets of the Akashans, once known as “the Space Gods.”

To accomplish this, the heroes must not only defeat some familiar enemies armed with new powers and treacheries, but also fight against many never-beforeseen foes (including previews of future creatures and abilities coming in the Pan-Pacific, Tharkhold, and Orrorsh releases). This sprawling seven-act adventure spans continents and realms, ushering the transition from Year One to Year Two!

INSIDE YOU‘LL FIND:
• A seven act adventure set in the realities of all of the cosms invading Earth.
• A choice which will have a major impact on the future of the Possibility Wars.
• New villains and Threats to fight and Eternity Shards to acquire!

boardgame.name: Spider-Sister
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

“They came from the ceiling!”

Spider-Sisters are ambush hunters of the wastes and ruins and aptly named after both their uncanny ability to climb walls and hang from ceilings, but so too, their venomous bite which causes paralysis. When these things feed on an unlucky excavator, they are conscious as it bleeds them out, able to feel, see, and hear everything as they meet their end. Will your player character be the ones to rid these foul things and save the captives, or will they too succumb?

This is our 9th Monday Mutant of an initial 12 creature assortment. Included in this 6 page PDF are tables for mutations, contents of their carried pouch, and art and stats for the elusive, huge alpha male. Snag your PDF copy of this fast-moving, wall crawlin' blood drinker for the always affordable 'Pay What You Want' price.

boardgame.name: Adventure Framework Collection #2
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Harken and Glad Meeting, traveller!

This 208 page softcover (full size 8.5" x 11") is a compilation of Fourteen Colour Adventure Frameworks (no’s 47-60) providing a range of short, independent adventures set in common locations such as towns, mountains, jungles, forests, lakes, swamps and plains.

List of Adventures:

Blight Over Brynderwold (47)
Tower of Baal (48)
Nest Beyond the Stars (49)
Night at the Green Goblin (50)
Assault on Dunmark (51)
A Creeping Tide (52)
The Astravali (53)
Rise of the Starborn (54)
Well of Demons (55)
Shadow Over Wistwood (56)
Fens of Molot Baat (57)
Cliffs of Elletarn (58)
Prophet of the Pit People (59)
Winterwold (60)
Specifically designed for low prep, improvised play, each framework comes with hooks/rumours, a core scenario, NPC details & statistics, random encounters, and colour art. Thirteen of the adventures include hand drawn maps.

Armed with this compilation, filling your sandbox with small - medium sized adventures has never been easier. Browse the collection, throw out a few hooks, and let the players bite where they may. Whichever direction they take, you'll be ready to handle it with aplomb.

boardgame.name: Video Game Powers
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Since their creation, Video Games have been sources of fun and outlets of stress throughout popular culture. Heroes with the power to manifest digital constructs, physics and abilities in the real world occupy a literal meeting point between imagination and popular culture, where all things probable become possible. Video game powers range a broad spectrum wherein crafting pixelated constructs, unleashing blasts of energy or deadly fighting abilities are just the tip of the iceberg.

This sourcebook contains:

Expanded War Descriptors and Video Game Features
Offensive Powers: Data Disc, Cut & Paste and Mortal Fighter Combo
Defensive Powers: Bubble Shield, Digital DNA, Respawn and two more powers
Movement Powers: Drowning Disabled, Overclock Mode and two more powers
Utility Powers: Alternate Vision Mode, Gamimancy, skins and two more powers
Other Powers: Power Gauntlet, Power Ups, Switch Equipment
War Complications: Derezzed, Digital Native, Retro and two more complications

boardgame.name: Bounty Hunter Ship Names
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Hunting down fugitives wherever they go, bounty hunters always get their target. Download d66 Bounty Hunter Ship Names and make their ship names as cool as they are.
23 Detective Slaughter
33 Freedom's Nemesis
55 Steel Manacles

boardgame.name: Terra System: Outer Planets Station and Facility Names
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The outer planets of our solar system were colonized long before humanity developed the technology to jump to different solar systems. Each of those facilities and space stations has a name. So if you want to game in our solar system, you don't have to worry about naming them with d66 Terra System: Outer Planets Station and Facility Names.
14 Correctional Facility Io
41 Muxingzhan (Jupiter Station)
62 Titan Fuel Refinery Centre

boardgame.name: Vehicle Manufacturer Names
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

d66 Vehicle Manufacturer Names delivers 36 names for vehicle manufacturers. Whether you are looking for a massive, multi-planetary corporation that produces gravcars and much more or a small local specialty company that hand makes flyers and ground cars, this list is here to help.
14 Aurora Skycars
24 Deep Blue Submersibles
52 Quadssytem Sports Cars

boardgame.name: Things That Happened While You Were in Jump Space
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Quite a bit can happen during that week when you are in jump space. The last you heard, all was fine on the planet and you emerge to food riots, a megacorp announce expansion plans, or perhaps war broke out. Perhaps something happened on your ship while you were away from reality, like a powersurge sending you off course or someone in low berth is suddenly pregnant and the unborn is experiencing rapid gestation. The list d66 Things That Happened While You Were in Jump Space will help you make a unique experience.

22 Death of Important Person: Planet is in mourning following the sudden demise of someone beloved
25 Economic Boon: All cargoes sell for 125% of normal price and buying cargo costs 90% of normal price
63 Speed Germination: A small tree grew in cargo hold or other unoccupied part of the ship

boardgame.name: Ships Named After a Breakup/Divorce
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Not everyone names a ship after good times or happy memories. Some do it after a major life change. Inside d66 Ships Named After a Breakup/Divorce you'll find all kinds of ship names that will help you give the ship's captain or owner some personality.
14 Broken Heart
32 I Am Resilient
45 Pheonix

boardgame.name: Reasons Traffic Control has Denied Take Off Clearance
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Traffic control doesn't always let you leave a star system when you want to. There can be a whole host of reason why they may say no, and d66 Reasons Traffic Control has Denied Take Off Clearance presents you with 36 such reasons. Use them in your game today.
13 Communication with navigation satellites is offline
35 Intelligence official denied departure, no additional details
62 Traffic official's license expired, finishing recertification now

boardgame.name: Salvage Ship Names
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Trolling through a solar system looking for scrap metal or heavily damaged ships, scavengers are everywhere. Never be without a name for their ship. Download d66 Salvage Ship Names now.
21 Harvester
25 Klunk Bucket
63 We Will Wreck You

boardgame.name: Random Things Found in a Ship's Hold 2
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A considerable amount of junk and random items can accumulate in a cargo hold over time. So give the cargo hold of the ship some character with d66 Random Things Found in a Ship’s Hold 2.
16 Bust of a famous people sculpted in lava stone
33 Holographic equipment, sword training program loaded
55 Ship interior components, all pink

boardgame.name: Gas Giant Names
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Gas giants mean free fuel for your crew. Give each one a name with d66 Gas Giant Names and make each and every one memorable.
15 Bright Eye
36 Leviathan
54 Shang Di

boardgame.name: Reasons Why Your Robot is Ignoring You
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Your robots should always obey your orders. But why is this one not? Come up with an excellent reason why not with d66 Reasons Why Your Robot is Ignoring You and make this game memorable.
22 Does not feel like serving you today
24 Error in language files, does not understand you
64 Will not act unless you say, "please."

boardgame.name: Monopoly: Bilbao
boardgame.description:
Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Bilbao, in the Basque country, in Spain.

boardgame.name: Hi Mi Ki
boardgame.description:
Hi Mi Ki is a game picturing a showdown between japanese elementalists, Yamabushis.

The game relies on a cube tipping mechanic.
(Cube, not dice because they are NOT thrown in Himiki.)

Each cube figures Water, Fire and Wood on its faces. At your turn you can tip one of your cubes to the next square of the board. This way your cubes change facing as they move on the board.

When your cube ends its movement on a square beside an enemy cube there is a confrontation. Water quenches fire, fire burns wood and wood floats on water.

If your cube is victorious you take a victory tile. The first player with 6 tiles wins the game. If your cube is on the same side as an adjacent cube you get to play again.

The difficulty of the game is to keep track of the always changing cubes on the board.

Solo play and 2 vs 2 play are also available in the base game.

-description from designer

boardgame.name: Linjaa
boardgame.description:
Creating the longest line, flip your opponent's plan or just enjoy the puzzle: it's up to you to choose a winning strategy.
Each card in the game is unique, so it's not easy to form the longest line.
Win or lose, you always create a compelling pattern with Linjaa.

Linjaa is a multi-player edge-matching game. When adding a new card to the playing field, you gather points when finishing a line or a "circle" (closing a shape). Cards can only be combined when the lines on your card match the lines on the cards already in the field.
Concentrate on your own plan or sabotage the plans of your fellow players: it's up to you to choose which line to take.
Whoever succeeds in finishing the most and the longest lines or closing the largest shapes, wins the game.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Origins: Ankunft der Erbauer
Origins: First Builders
Origins: Los Primeros Constructores
Origins: Pierwsi Budowniczowie
Origins: Primeiros Construtores
Истоки: Восход цивилизаций
오리진스: 최초의 건축가들
boardgame.description:
They came to this planet, and they chose you. They uplifted your people and promised great prosperity. They provided the wisdom and the resources to build your cities sky high. They taught you the ways of culture, science, and warfare. They promised knowledge for any willing to learn. Come, Archon, guide your citizens to victory, under the watchful eyes of the Builders, our benefactors from beyond the skies above.

In Origins: First Builders, you are an archon, guiding a population of freemen, influencing the construction of buildings and monuments, climbing the three mighty zodiac temples, and taking part in an arms race — all in an effort to leave the greatest mark on mankind's ancient history.

You start the game with a city consisting of just two building tiles: the Agora tile and the Palace tile. As the game develops, your city will grow in both size and strength as you add new building tiles, each of which has a special ability that triggers when it is first added to a city and when closing a district. Your placement on the military track indicates the rewards you receive when you attack and your chances of becoming first player.

Origins: First Builders is played over a number of rounds, with a round ending only after each player has passed. If a game end condition has not yet been triggered, the game continues with a new round. On your turn, you perform one of the following actions:

• Visit an encounter site with your workers to gain resources and additional citizen or speaker dice, advance on the zodiac temple tracks (and potentially gain zodiac cards), and advance and attack on the military track.

• Close a district, gaining victory points (VPs) and possibly gold for matching a district card's building pattern, additional bonuses based on the buildings you activate, and additional VPs at the end of the game based on the value of the citizen die you use to close the district.

• Build a tower level to increase your endgame scoring based on the tower heights and the matching color dice you use to close your districts.

• Grow your population.

• Pass.

The game finishes at the end of the round when one or more of the following conditions has been met:

At most three colors of tower disks are still in stock.
No gold remains above any district card.
No citizen die of the proper color can be added to the citizen offer.
A player has moved all three of their zodiac disks to the top space of each temple track.


The temple area is divided into three tracks: the sea temple, the forest temple, and the mountain temple. You score points only for your two least-valued temples, and once all the points have been summed, whoever has the most VPs wins.

boardgame.name: Zapotec
boardgame.description:
The Zapotec were a pre-Columbian civilization that flourished in the Valley of Oaxaca in Mesoamerica. Archaeological evidence reveal their culture going back at least 2,500 years. Remnants of the ancient city of Monte Albán in the form of buildings, ball courts, magnificent tombs, and finely worked gold jewelry testify of this once great civilization. Monte Albán was one of the first major cities in Mesoamerica and the center of the Zapotec state that dominated much of the territory that today belongs to the Mexican state of Oaxaca.

In a game of Zapotec, you build temples, cornfields and villages in the three valleys surrounding the capital to generate resources needed for building pyramids, making sacrifices to the gods, and performing rituals.

Each round, players simultaneously pick a card from their hand to determine their turn order and the resources they collect. Players then perform individual turns and spend resources to build new houses, gain access to special abilities, make sacrifices to the gods and build pyramids. The played action card determines three important aspects of each player's turn:


The resource printed at the top of the card determines the row or column to activate on the resource grid to collect income.



The icon in the middle of the card matches one of the nine properties of the building spaces on the map (one of three building types, one of three regions, or one of three terrain types). On their turn, players may build only on spaces that match that icon.



The number at the bottom of the card dictates the turn order for the round when the card is played.


At the end of the round, players draft new cards from the central offer, with the final undrafted card becoming the scoring bonus card for the following round.

After five rounds, players score points for pyramids, for their position on the sacrifice track, and for their ritual cards. The player with the most victory points wins.

—description from publisher

boardgame.name: Friends: The One With the Apartment Bet Game
boardgame.description:
Show off your Friends trivia with the Friends: The One with the Apartment Bet Game. This hilarious party game makes the perfect night in for fans of the classic sitcom. The Friends board game is based on the game played in "The One with the Embryos," when Monica and Rachel wager their apartment in a trivia game against Chandler and Joey.

Take on show trivia in 4 categories: Fears & Peeves, Ancient History, Literature and It’s All Relative. The super speedy lightening round, with even more show trivia, can put it all on the line.

Choose your wager, whether it’s cooking the other team a meal or cleaning the bathroom for a month. But don’t worry – in this Friends board game, you can keep your apartment!

Contents: Friends Bet Game board, 250 cards, timer, 2 dry erase cards and 2 dry erase markers.

boardgame.description: Dandelion, a story game for one player.

boardgame.name: The Cost of Hope
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Cost of Hope is a three-part adventure for three to four Tier 2 (6-9th level) players, set in our Cities of Myth: Fallen Camelot setting for 5e. Each part should take 1 or 2 sessions.

During these three adventures, explorers will gather different artifacts for Sir Dristan (a descendant of one of the Knights of the Round Table) from empty tombs and dragon lairs. Sir Dristan is willing to sacrifice himself to transform into a black knight, a power with which he can defeat Queen Morgana. Will the explorers help him, or will they find another way?

Filled with puzzles, epic battles, hidden secrets, and wondrous magic items, the Cost of Hope has something for every table and every play style. Will you make Sir Dristan pay the cost to hope for a better future?

Included in this adventure:

Part 1: The Tomb of Lord Alfraec. Filled with traps, puzzles, and secret doors.
Part 2: The Lair of Zallzavier. Fight an undead dragon, cure a corrupted land, and recieve magic items like the bite of pride and drop of the moon
Part 3: Trial of the Black Knight. Navigate your way through a series of rooms and various encounters. At the end, choose your side and fight either the Black Knight or the Champion of Morgana.
Where to go from here. This adventure presents options to integrate it into a larger campaign to more fully immerse the party in the world of Fallen Camelot.

boardgame.name: Best Possible Life
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

While traveling across the plains of Illinois (or other rural location of your choosing), the heroes come under attack from a strange extra-dimensional creature. Tracking it back to a lone farmhouse, they must confront a mad scientist who has just opened a gateway to yet another alternate universe.

Best Possible Life is a One-Sheet Scenario designed for use with Dime Adventures: Pulp Alternate History Roleplaying.
